'''''Polyporus alveolaris''''', commonly known as the '''hexagonal-pored polypore''',<ref name="urlPolyporus alveolaris"/> is a species of [[fungus]] in the genus [[Polyporus]]. It causes a [[white rot]] of dead [[hardwood]]s. Found on sticks and decaying logs, its distinguishing features are its yellowish to orange scaly [[pileus (mycology)|cap]], and the hexagonal or diamond-shaped pores. It is widely distributed in North America, and also found in Asia, Australia, and Europe.

==Taxonomy==
The first scientific [[species description|description]] of the fungus was published in 1815 by [[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle]], under the name ''Merulius alveolaris''.<ref name=DeCandolle1815/> A few years later in 1821 it was [[sanctioned name|sanctioned]] by [[Elias Magnus Fries]] as ''Cantharellus alveolaris''. It was transferred to the genus ''Polyporus'' in a 1941 publication by [[Appollinaris Semenovich Bondartsev]] and [[Rolf Singer]].<ref name=Bondartsev1941/>

The [[genus]] name is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] meaning "many pores", while the [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''alveolaris'' means "with small pits or hollows".<ref name="urlMushroomExpert"/>

==Description==
[[File:Polyporus alveolaris pores.jpg|thumb|left|The hexagonal pores are a characteristic feature]]
The fruit bodies of ''P. alveolaris'' are {{convert|1|–|10|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter, rounded to kidney- or fan-shaped. Fruit bodies sometimes have stems, but they are also found attached directly to the growing surface. The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] surface is dry, covered with silk-like fibrils, and is an orange-yellow or reddish-orange color, which weathers to cream to white. The [[Trama (mycology)|context]] is thin (2 mm), tough, and white. Tubes are radially elongates, with the pore walls breaking down in age. The pores are large—compared to other species in this genus—typically 0.5–3 mm wide, angular (diamond-shaped) or hexagonal; the pore surface is a white to buff color. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]], if present, is 0.5–2 cm long  by  1.5–5 mm thick, placed either laterally or centrally, and has a white to tan color. The pores extend decurrently on the stipe. The [[spore print|spore deposit]] is white.

===Microscopic features===

[[Basidiospore|Spores]] are narrowly elliptical and smooth, [[hyaline]], with dimensions of 11–14.5  × 4–5 [[micrometre|µm]]. The [[basidia]] are club-shaped and four-spored, with dimensions of 28–42 × 7–9 µm.<ref name="urlEoL"/>

===Similar species===
''Polyporus craterellus'' bears a resemblance to ''P. alveolaris'', but the former species has a more prominent stalk and does not have the reddish-orange colors observed in the latter.<ref name=Roody2003/>

===Edibility===

Opinions are divided on the edibility of this species. One source describes ''P. alveolaris'' as inedible,<ref name="urlMushroomExpert"/> while others say "edible but tough".<ref name="urlRogers"/>

==Habitat and distribution==

''Polyporus alveolaris'' is found growing singly or grouped together on branches and twigs of [[hardwood]]s, commonly on [[shagbark hickory]] in the spring and early summer.<ref name=Healy2003/> It has been reported growing on the dead hardwoods of genera ''[[Acer (genus)|Acer]]'',''[[Castanea (genus)|Castanea]]'', ''[[Cornus (genus)|Cornus]]'', ''[[Corylus]]'', ''[[Cratageus]]'', ''[[Erica]]'', ''[[Fagus (tree)|Fagus]]'', ''[[Fraxinus]]'', ''[[Juglans]]'', ''[[Magnolia]]'', ''[[Morus (plant)|Morus]]'', ''[[Populus]]'', ''[[Pyrus]]'', ''[[Robinia]]'', ''[[Quercus]]'', ''[[Syringa]], [[Tilia]]'', and ''[[Ulmus]]''.<ref name=Ryvarden1993/>

This species is widely distributed in North America,<ref name="urlMushroomExpert"/><ref name= Healy2003/>
and has also been collected in Australia,<ref name=May2003/> China,<ref name=Zhuang2001/> and Europe (Czechoslovakia,<ref name=Kotlaba1957/> Italy<ref name=Govi1970/> and Portugal<ref name=Melo1978/>).

==Antifungal compounds==

A [[polypeptide]] with [[Antifungal medication|antifungal]] properties has been isolated from the fresh fruit bodies of this species. Named alveolarin, it inhibits the growth of the species ''[[Botrytis cinerea]]'',''[[Fusarium oxysporum]]'', ''[[Mycosphaerella arachidicola]]'' and ''[[Physalospora piricola]]''.<ref name=Wang2004/>
